q: Donald Rumsfeld was at odds with Secretary of State href="http://www.foxnews.com/topics/politics/Colin Powell-Colin Powell.htm#r_src=ramp"> Colin Powell about Iraq. The differences were not personal, Donald Rumsfeld says. He recalls receiving a book that Henry Kissinger had written, with the inscription, To an occasional adversary and a permanent friend. `` When I started working on the book, Henry Kissinger said,` You tell it like it was.' We differed on some issues, and there's nothing wrong with that. It was professional

With a general election imminent, Fine Gael finance spokesman Michael Noonan told the Irish Times that his party would want to see tests carried out before providing further funding for any troubled banks. If there is no government until somewhere on March 9th, or some days later, I think it's prudent for an incoming government to wait for the results of the stress testing before they commit, he commented. Labour leader Eamon Gilmore went even further than Mr Michael Noonan , stating that his group was not likely to support further taxpayer backing for the Bank of Ireland, Allied Irish Banks or the EBS building
